...things like the young girl in India having four legs and four arms?
 
 On the news this morning, there's a corp of about 30 doctors operating on this four year old to remove two of her legs and two of her arms. Since her birth, she's been hailed as a goddess in her village, she's been offered a paid position in a freak show and she's been studied by serious medical people.
 
 What causes this kind of deformity in humans, goats, cattle etc wherein they develop too many appendages? I've seen a two headed goat, a six legged calf and a six legged bullfrog (deemed illegal in frog jumping contests).

...things like the young girl in India having four legs and four arms?
 
 On the news this morning, there's a corp of about 30 doctors operating on this four year old to remove two of her legs and two of her arms. Since her birth, she's been hailed as a goddess in her village, she's been offered a paid position in a freak show and she's been studied by serious medical people.
 
 What causes this kind of deformity in humans, goats, cattle etc wherein they develop too many appendages? I've seen a two headed goat, a six legged calf and a six legged bullfrog (deemed illegal in frog jumping contests).

 
 Not really my area of expertise, so this is just a guess.
 
 When you first develop, you're a mass of undifferentiated cells. As the cells accumulate, chemical cues start to organize the cells. Up and down, left and right, front and back get assigned. Then other cues start telling cells to become certain things. Organs, limbs, etc. Some region gets told, "you're going to be the head", and a head starts growing there, which is to say the cells there, instead of being undifferentiated, start turning into the cells you would expect in a head.
 
 All that I'm sure of, now here comes the guess. If, early in the "you're going to become a head" process a cell splits when it wasn't supposed to, then both new cells could get the "you, you become the head" cue. And so they both try to become the head. Now, four arms and four legs is probably the result of something a bit more complicated than a simple case of an unexpected cell division, but probably not hugely more. Some cue got doubled up some how and so two sets of limbs grew.

I think it's a case of conjoined twins (rump-to-rump) where one twin failed to develop a head and full torso. There's a picture with an x-ray here. Apparently it's called isciopagus -- never seen anything like it.
 
 As to why there are occasionally duplicated appendages, it's probably a fault with normal development, similar in type, perhaps, to cases such as the bithorax mutation in fruit flies where a fly develops two thoraces.

There's a very nice summary of how Hox genes control the number, type and position of vertebrae in vertebrates during development here
 
 Of course, this doesn't completely explain the duplication of entire limbs, that's probably a more complex developmental flaw, but it's almost undoubtedly of a similar nature.

I think it's a case of conjoined twins (rump-to-rump) where one twin failed to develop a head and full torso. There's a picture with an x-ray here. Apparently it's called isciopagus -- never seen anything like it.
 

 
 Yeah, that does seem a far more likely explanation.

...things like the young girl in India having four legs and four arms?
 
 On the news this morning, there's a corp of about 30 doctors operating on this four year old to remove two of her legs and two of her arms. Since her birth, she's been hailed as a goddess in her village, she's been offered a paid position in a freak show and she's been studied by serious medical people.
 
 What causes this kind of deformity in humans, goats, cattle etc wherein they develop too many appendages? I've seen a two headed goat, a six legged calf and a six legged bullfrog (deemed illegal in frog jumping contests).

 
 
 In this case, it was a 'parasitic' twin that got reabsorbed. 
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parasitic_twin

The short explanation is simply Murphies Law. If anything can go wrong it will. And in human development many things can go wrong. Its not a fault tolerant design - bad planning on the designers part.
It's evidence of EAM. Probably she comes from a large family. Her mother always had her hands full and was on her feet day and night.emoticon_xclown
